message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of protein accumulations in the heart, atria, and lungs, without plasma cell dyscrasia, suggests that these are amyloid deposits. Among the options, only normal transthyretin is a known cause of amyloid deposition in cardiac tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of abnormal, insoluble protein aggregates in the ventricular walls and atria, and a lack of plasma cell dyscrasia indicates that the most likely cause is normal transthyretin amyloidosis, which is characterized by the deposition of insoluble transthyretin protein in various organs, including the heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of insoluble protein aggregates in the ventricular walls and atria points towards amyloidosis. Among the options, transthyretin is the most commonly affected protein in cardiac amyloidosis in older adults. Natriuretic peptide is not typically associated with amyloidosis, immunoglobulin light chain is associated with multiple myeloma, and serum amyloid A is associated with inflammatory diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches with the cardiac amyloidosis, which is caused by the deposition of abnormal insoluble protein fibrils in the heart, which is most commonly composed of normal transthyretin. Other options do not match the description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of abnormal insoluble protein aggregations in the heart, atria, and lungs suggests cardiac amyloidosis, which is most commonly caused by deposition of transthyretin amyloid. The other options listed are not typically associated with cardiac amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ventricular thickening and abnormal protein aggregations suggest cardiac amyloidosis. Among the options, normal transthyretin is most commonly associated with cardiac amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the abnormal protein aggregations is consistent with amyloidosis, and among the options, only normal transthyretin is known to cause cardiac amyloidosis. Natriuretic peptide is a hormone produced by the heart, Immunoglobulin light chain is associated with light chain amyloidosis, and serum amyloid A is associated with secondary amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description suggests that the patient has cardiac amyloidosis, and the most common type of cardiac amyloidosis is associated with the deposition of normal transthyretin. The other options are not associated with cardiac amyloidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of abnormal, insoluble protein filaments in the heart suggests amyloidosis. Among the options, normal transthyretin is the most common cause of cardiac amyloidosis in the elderly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest cardiac amyloidosis, and among the options, only normal transthyretin is associated with this condition. Natriuretic peptide is used to manage heart failure, immunoglobulin light chain is associated with light chain amyloidosis, and serum amyloid A is associated with inflammatory conditions.
